title-group.article-title: Improved low-frequency performance of a composite sound absorption coating

abstract.p: In order to improve the low-frequency acoustic performance, a composite sound absorption coating made by embedding another viscoelastic material into the viscoelastic substrate of the traditional sound absorption coating, has been developed. Compared to the substrate, the transverse wave speed of the embedded-layer is lower. Accounting for the symmetry, the unit cell of the traditional sound absorption coating or the composite sound absorption coating could be approximately regarded as a viscoelastic single-layer cylindrical tube or a viscoelastic double-layer cylindrical tube, respectively. The plane wave normally impinging on the sound absorption coating only excites the axisymmetric wave propagating in the axial direction of the viscoelastic cylindrical tube. If the complex axisymmetric wave number and the effective impedance of the viscoelastic cylindrical tube are obtained, the acoustic performance of the sound absorption coating could be evaluated by using the transfer matrix method, which is suitable for both the single-layer cylindrical tube and the double-layer cylindrical tube. Numerical results show that the peak frequency of the sound absorption coefficient is shifted to the lower location as the proportion of the embedded-layer increases, or the transverse wave speed of the embedded-layer decreases.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Analysis of sound absorption coatings containing periodic cavities were started with the work of Meyer et al. (1958). Gaunaurd (1977, 1985) and Lane (1981) presented a one-dimensional analysis method for a viscoelastic medium containing short cylindrical cavities, and provided a physical explanation based on different modes of resonances correlated with different physical dimensions of cavities. Jackins and Gaunaurd (1983) used the resonance scattering theory to predict the reflection characteristics of bilaminar coatings, where each layer containing spherical cavities of small concentration can be described by an effective medium. As a related problem, studies on the reflection of a plane wave impinging upon such bilaminar structure have been finished by Strifors and Gaunaurd (1990). They concluded that the coating should always be analyzed with the structure behind the coating. He and Wang (1996) studied the performances of non-homogeneous sound absorption structures. Based upon the viscoelastic material assumed to be the highly viscous fluid, they derived the transfer matrix of the non-homogeneous structure. Tang et al. (2005) presented a two-dimensional analytic model to analyze the reflection performances of sound absorption coatings which contain periodic cylindrical cavities.

Besides analytical methods, the finite element method (FEM) has been widely used to estimate the performances of sound absorption coatings. Hennion et al. (1990) used a two dimensional FEM to analyze the scattering of an infinite, uniform, plane grating of compliant tubes. Furthermore, Hennion and Decarpigny (1991) developed the FEM to the three-dimensional to analyze the Alberich coating which could be considered as a doubly periodic elastic structure, and compared to previous analytical results or to experimental results to validate the accuracy of the approach. Then, Easwaran and Munjal (1993) presented another 3D FEM to analyze the reflection characteristics of resonant sound absorbers. The difference is the modal summation technique in the fluid in Hennion and Decarpigny (1991) is replaced by the specified impedance boundary conditions. Tan et al. (2003) used an FEM to analyze the acoustic performance of a viscoelastic layer adhered to a steel plate, where the viscoelastic layer may contain periodic spherical, cylindrical or conical cavities. Panigrahi et al. (2008) used a modified hybrid type FEM to investigate different kinds of underwater acoustic coatings. Recently, Ivansson (2006, 2008) used the technique which is applied in the electron scattering and the band-gap computations for photonic crystals, to investigate viscoelastic sound absorption coatings containing periodic spherical, or superellipsoidal cavities.

In the case of viscoelastic composite materials containing spherical cavities, Meyer et al. (1958) and Gaunaurd and Uberall (1979) presented that the resonant frequency decreases with the drop of the transverse wave speed, which results in the improvement of the sound absorption performance at low frequencies. According to this conclusion, the present paper is to establish an analytical model of the composite sound absorption coating, which is made by embedding another viscoelastic material with lower transverse wave speed into the substrate just as shown in Figure 1. The traditional sound absorption coatings as mentioned in the above papers is generally made up of only one viscoelastic material, so it may be the most significant difference compared to the composite sound absorption coating. The plane wave obliquely impinging on the sound absorption coating will excites non-axisymmetric wave propagating in the viscoelastic cylindrical tube, which much increases the difficulty in the analytical calculation, so only the normally incident case is considered in this paper. Additionally, the effect of the embedded-layer properties on the sound absorption performance will also be numerically discussed. Figure 1.
Configurations of the traditional and the composite sound absorption coatings.

sec.title: 2. Prediction model
sec.p: A typical configuration of sound absorption coating contains cylindrical cavities or conical cavities. Since cavities are periodically distributed, only one unit cell of the sound absorption coating would be taken into account when the plane wave normally incidents. As shown in Figure 1, the external boundary of the cell is hexagonal while the internal boundary is cylindrical or conical, which makes it difficult to analytically evaluate the acoustic performance. For the sake of simplification, the hexagonal external boundary is replaced by the cylindrical external boundary. Moreover, the conical cavity is approximated by the combination of several cylindrical cavities also as shown in Figure 1, so the cell would be regarded as the combination of single-layer cylindrical tubes, or the combination of double-layer cylindrical tubes, which respectively corresponds to the traditional sound absorption coating and the composite sound absorption coating.

As is well known, sound absorption coatings are generally made up of viscoelastic materials. When the plane wave normally incidents on the sound absorption coating, only the axisymmetric wave propagating in the vertical direction (the axial direction) of the cylindrical tube is excited, so the complex wave number including the propagation constant and the attenuation constant could be used to estimate the performance of the sound absorption coating. Besides, Tang et al. (2005) indicated that the low-frequency performance of the sound absorption coating is dominantly determined by the lowest axisymmetric wave. Thus, it is important to acquire the lowest complex wave number by solving the characteristic equation of the axisymmetric wave firstly. Then, the effective impedance of the cylindrical tube will be calculated when the effective axial stress and the effective axial displacement are averaged along the radial direction. Naturally, the single-layer or the double-layer cylindrical tube could be regarded as a transfer line, so the input impedance at the interface between the sound absorption coating and the water medium will be obtained by using the transfer matrix. Finally, it is not difficult to calculate the reflection coefficient of the sound absorption coating.

Figure 6 shows the effect of the embedded-layer thickness on the sound absorption performance under the absolute rigid termination, where the embedded material E1 is selected. The outer, middle and inner radii of the double-layer cylindrical tube are listed in the figure, and the height of the sound absorption coating is 40 mm. As mentioned above, because the transverse wave speed of the embedded-layer is lower than that of the substrate, the phase velocity of the axisymmetric wave decreases. Note that the resonant frequency of the sound absorption coating depends on the phase velocity, so the peak frequency of the sound absorption coefficient is shifted to the lower location when the proportion of the embedded-layer increases, which can be seen in the figure. Figure 6.

Figure 7 shows the effect of the embedded-layer properties on the sound absorption performance under the absolute rigid termination. The outer, middle and inner radii of the double-layer cylindrical tube are 10 mm, 3 mm and 2 mm respectively, and the height of the sound absorption coating also is 40 mm. We can find that the peak frequency of the sound absorption coefficient is around 3600 Hz when the embedded material E1 is selected, while the peak frequency is about 3100 Hz when the embedded material E2 is chosen. Thus, it indicates another possible way to improve the low-frequency performance of the sound absorption coating by embedding the viscoelastic material with low transverse wave speed. Figure 7.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: In order to improve the low-frequency acoustic performance, a composite sound absorption coating made by embedding another viscoelastic material into the viscoelastic substrate of the traditional sound absorption coating, has been developed in this paper. Several cases of the composite sound absorption coating have been numerically simulated and compared, so we can conclude that:

For the viscoelastic double-layer cylindrical tube, the phase velocity of the axisymmetric wave decreases at low frequencies as: (a) the proportion of the embedded-layer increases; (b) the transverse wave speed of the embedded-layer decreases. Since the resonant frequency of the sound absorption coating depends on the phase velocity of the axisymmetric wave, the peak frequency of the sound absorption coefficient is shifted to the lower location, which indicates the sound absorption performance at low frequencies has been improved.
